The Buddha said:
The music of Zhantan's instruments is like this. Because of this music, it causes people to give rise to the bodhisattva mind. This person's virtue is extremely thick.
When the Buddha spoke of Zhantan's merits, at that time those in the assembly all spontaneously had flowers on their lapels. They all stood up, held the flowers, and scattered them over Zhantan.
At that time, Zhantan received the flowers with his right shoulder. The flowers did not fall to the ground. He then held the flowers and made offerings by scattering them over the Buddha.
The flowers then transformed into a jeweled flower canopy above the Buddha, covering the thousand buddha lands.
In the flower canopy, billions and trillions of pearl treasures were suspended in each place. The light of each pearl emitted billions of lights.
Each light had a lotus flower, with various colors and a very fragrant scent.
On each lotus flower, there was a sitting Buddha like Shakyamuni, all saying:
Excellent, excellent!
The number of people transformed by you, Dantuo Luo, is very many, and they have all given rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.

The deeds of this Bodhisattva have already transcended the realm, and his own realm is also manifested. He has gone beyond birth and death, yet he still sees as before. He abides in nirvana and the three realms, practicing for the sake of all people.
Dantuo Luo thought of the sitting Buddhas and wanted to hold jeweled flower canopies to cover them all. At that moment, he entered samadhi, and the samadhi was called Adorned Canopy.
Then, above the sitting Buddhas, there were flower canopies, and each of the Bodhisattvas, bhikshus, and those in the assembly had their own flower canopy, holding the canopies in their hands.
All the bodhisattvas, bhiká¹£us, and assembly held flower canopies to make offerings to the buddhas above.

I only wish that you will use the time to trouble the honored gods.

I only wish that you will use the time to trouble the honored gods.

The Buddha said to the bodhisattva Tiwuli:
Bodhisattvas practice the perfection of giving in thirty-two ways, practicing it purely.
What are the thirty-two things?
First, bodhisattvas give in order to seek Buddhahood, with the mind of enlightenment as the basis;
Second, when bodhisattvas practice giving, they should avoid the paths of arhats and pratyekabuddhas;
Third, when bodhisattvas practice giving, they should think of delivering the people of the ten directions;
Fourth, when bodhisattvas practice giving to others, their minds should not regret it;
Fifth, when bodhisattvas practice giving to others, they should view them as Buddhas;
Sixth, when bodhisattvas practice giving to others, their minds should be free from stinginess and greed;
Seventh, when bodhisattvas practice giving to others, their minds should be undisturbed, and they should give joyfully;
Eighth, when bodhisattvas practice giving to others, they should personally measure out the gifts;

Ninth, when bodhisattvas practice giving to others, their intentions should be vast and not reckless;ğŸ”½Tenth, when bodhisattvas practice giving to others, they should not seek to be reborn in any particular place;
Eleventh, when bodhisattvas practice giving to others, they should not have any expectations in return;
Twelfth, when bodhisattvas practice giving to others, they should not place their hopes anywhere, but follow the teachings of the Buddha's scriptures;
Thirteenth, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is because they delight in the Buddha's teachings;
Fourteenth, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is because they wish to seek the Buddha's path;
Fifteenth, when bodhisattvas give to others, they do not become arrogant;
Sixteenth, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is because they wish to encourage and teach others;
Seventeenth, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is because they wish to liberate people;
Eighteenth, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is because they wish to uphold the Dharma and teach people;
Nineteenth, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is because they follow the Buddha's teachings;
Twentieth, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is because they wish to subdue the demons and their retinue;
Twenty-first, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is because they wish to achieve and attain Buddhahood;
Twenty-second, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is because they wish to become the hero among men;
Twenty-third, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is to block off the path of hungry ghosts;
Twenty-fourth, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is to cause them to practice giving in future lives;
Twenty-fifth, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is to attain noble and wealthy happiness in future lives;

Thirtieth, when bodhisattvas give to others, it is to cause the bodhisattvas to be accomplished in return;
Thirty-first, a bodhisattva gives to others in order to attain the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks;
Thirty-second, a bodhisattva gives to others in order to perfect the adornments of the realm and to approach the Buddha and enter into the various sutra teachings.
These are the thirty-two pure acts of a bodhisattva's giving. A bodhisattva's practice of the perfection of giving is like this.
A bodhisattva's pure practice of the perfection of morality has thirty-two aspects.
What are the thirty-two?
First, a bodhisattva's physical actions are always pure, which is upholding the precepts;
Second, a bodhisattva is free from stinginess, anger, and ignorance, and their speech is pure, which is upholding the precepts;
Third, a bodhisattva's mind is bright and wise, and they do not deceive the Buddha, which is upholding the precepts;
Fourth, a bodhisattva does not follow non-Buddhist paths and practices the ten wholesome deeds, which is upholding the precepts;
Fifth, bodhisattvas are always not apart from the Buddha's path in the heavens and the world, this is upholding the precepts;
Sixth, bodhisattvas are apart from arhats and pratyekabuddhas, and their minds are free from frivolousness, this is upholding the precepts;
Seventh, bodhisattvas are far removed from flattery and enter the Buddha's wisdom, this is upholding the precepts;
Eighth, bodhisattvas study extensively, and their wisdom-mind is foremost, this is upholding the precepts;

Tenth, bodhisattvas universally protect the people of the ten directions and are fully endowed, this is upholding the precepts;ğŸ”½Eleventh, bodhisattvas never violate the precepts and are free from shame and dishonor, this is upholding the precepts;ğŸ”½Twelfth, bodhisattvas do not violate or break [the precepts], and their actions are always fearful and cautious, this is upholding the precepts;

Fourteenth, bodhisattvas guard themselves and do not commit any evil, this is upholding the precepts;
Fifteenth, bodhisattvas follow the teachings of the enlightened ones to liberate the evil destinies, this is upholding the precepts;
Sixteenth, bodhisattvas uphold the precepts as the basis for rebirth in the heavens, this is upholding the precepts;
Seventeenth, bodhisattvas wish to fully possess the wisdom of the Buddha, this is upholding the precepts;
Eighteenth, bodhisattvas always firmly uphold the precepts and do not violate the Buddha's teachings, this is upholding the precepts;
Nineteenth, bodhisattvas do not become arrogant or despise others, always restraining themselves, this is upholding the precepts (one Dharma is missing in all the scriptures);
Twentieth, bodhisattvas are able to control their minds and not follow desire, this is upholding the precepts;
Twenty-first, bodhisattvas uphold the precepts without losing the Buddha's teachings, this is upholding the precepts;
Twenty-second, a bodhisattva upholds the precepts with faith, encouraging and assisting with joy, not deceiving, this is upholding the precepts;
Twenty-third, a bodhisattva does not violate stinginess and greed, this is upholding the precepts;
Twenty-fourth, a bodhisattva upholds the precepts firmly and abides by the Dharma to transform, this is upholding the precepts;
Twenty-fifth, a bodhisattva abandons wealth and always wishes to become a monk, this is upholding the precepts;
Twenty-sixth, a bodhisattva delights in practicing in a secluded place and delights in the sutra Dharma, this is upholding the precepts;

Twenty-seventh, a bodhisattva is not greedy for food, drink, or clothing, because he wishes to enter the Way, this is upholding the precepts;ğŸ”½Twenty-eighth, a bodhisattva cuts off all evils and accomplishes all merits, this is upholding the precepts;

Thirty, when bodhisattvas enter the profound Dharma practice, they are free from attachment, this is upholding the precepts;
Thirty-one, when bodhisattvas follow the sequential Dharma practice of the twelve links of dependent arising, this is upholding the precepts;

Thirty-two, when bodhisattvas do not follow the non-Buddhists and are free from the four inverted views, this is upholding the precepts.ğŸ”½These are the thirty-two aspects of the bodhisattvas' pure upholding of the precepts. The bodhisattvas' practice of the perfection of morality is like this.
The bodhisattvas' pure practice of the perfection of patience has thirty-two aspects.

One, when bodhisattvas are not attached to the body, this is patience;

Thirteenth, bodhisattvas never harbor anger towards others. This is patience.
Fourteenth, bodhisattvas protect others' minds and do not allow them to arise, this is patience;

Nineteenth, bodhisattvas do not hold grudges towards others, this is patience;
Twentieth, bodhisattvas keep themselves in check and do not commit any offenses, this is patience;
Twenty-first, bodhisattvas always control their minds and do not allow their thoughts to arise, this is patience;
Twenty-second, bodhisattvas can repent of their own faults, this is patience;
Twenty-third, bodhisattvas do not hold others' faults, this is patience;
Twenty-fourth, bodhisattvas always delight in contemplating the Buddha's path, this is patience;
Twenty-fifth, bodhisattvas always delight in understanding the sutras and Dharma, this is patience;ğŸ”½Twenty-sixth, bodhisattvas always love the people of the ten directions, this is patience;

Twenty-eighth, bodhisattvas always hold a harmonious mind towards others, this is patience;

Thirtieth, bodhisattvas always follow the sutras and Dharma without interruption, this is patience;
Thirty-first, bodhisattvas hear of the three treatments and are neither afraid nor terrified, this is patience;
Thirty-second, the bodhisattva has no place of origin, but delights in the wisdom of joy, this is patience.
These are the thirty-two matters of the bodhisattva's pure patience. The bodhisattva's practice of the perfection of patience is like this.
The bodhisattva's pure practice of the perfection of vigor has thirty-two matters.

Twenty-seventh, those who have not yet been liberated should all be liberated, those who have not yet heard the sÅ«tras should all be made to hear them, those who have not yet attained parinirvÄá¹‡a should all be made to attain parinirvÄá¹‡a, this is diligence;

Thirtieth, all birth and death originally come from nowhere, and going also does not reach anywhere, thoroughly understanding this, following worldly customs entering and expounding the Dharma for the people of the ten directions, rebirth and death manifesting in this way, this is lofty illumination;
Thirty-first, the four things to be guarded against are all attained through wisdom, and one thoroughly knows them all, this is lofty illumination;

Thirty-second, for the people of the ten directions, explain the sutra and Dharma, according to the people's preferences, and explain it for them. One should restrain one's mind and protect one's wisdom, and fully accomplish it. All Buddhas see from afar this lofty talent, and for the Bodhisattvas, they uphold the Buddha's majestic spirit and fully protect them.

The skillful means practiced by Bodhisattvas have thirty-two aspects.
What are the thirty-two aspects?
First, teach the people of the worlds in the ten directions to protect themselves;
Second, do not dwell in the midst of those with much merit, nor dwell in the midst of those with little merit;
Third, for the people of the worlds in the ten directions who seek the path of Bodhisattva, teach those who do not seek the path of Bodhisattva; view them all as teachers, no different;
Fourth, always wish to give many precious treasures and wealth to the masses;
Fifth, always happily seeking to teach people the RÄjagá¹›ha teachings;
Sixth, manifesting a woman's body to teach many women;
Seventh, manifesting as a youth to teach young children;
Eighth, manifesting as various kinds of people out of compassion for worldly people;
Ninth, for those in the world who are insane, also manifesting an insane body to peacefully liberate them;
Tenth, if there are those with disordered minds and confusion, according to their confusion, for them expounding the scriptures and path;
Eleventh, following the Dharma that people in the ten directions delight in, going to liberate them;
Twelfth, observing precepts for a hundred or a thousand years, if there are people who delight in giving up the precepts, going to teach and liberate them;
Thirteenth, according to the robes and various sounds and music that people delight in, giving these to people, none are not delighted, and using the scriptures and Dharma to teach them;
Fourteenth, for those ascetics with different aspirations and practices, he goes to teach them according to their Dharma practices;
Fifteenth, for those Nirgrantha Jains and other non-Buddhists, he enters and teaches them according to their kind, leading them into the Buddha's path;

Sixteenth, among the courtesans, he manifests as a handsome man to transform the courtesans, teaching them all to abstain from sexual activity and then transforming them into men, gradually leading them into the Buddha's path;

Seventeenth, if there are large gatherings playing various musical instruments, and spectators listening to the sounds of the music are all greatly delighted, he uses the sounds of the music to expound the Dharma, and those who hear it all attain liberation;
Eighteenth, he transforms his body into all the worldly craftsmen and artists, entering among them to teach and transform them for the sake of the Buddha's path;

Nineteenth, manifesting as a bhiká¹£u, for those in the world who are poor and weak, pointing out the treasures in the earth and giving them to the poor, and then teaching them the scriptures, causing them all to arouse the intention;

Twentieth, for those in the world who are mourning and crying out in grief, also manifesting majestic spiritual powers, also mourning and grieving, transforming and teaching those who are sorrowful to practice the scriptures;
Twenty-first, for those in the world who have lost their wealth, the Bodhisattva manifests and points out the hidden treasures, teaching them to practice the Way;

Twenty-second, if there are kings, ministers, or wealthy householders who are sorrowful due to having no children, then transforming and entering their wombs to become their child, for each of their parents and family members, teaching the scriptures and causing them to attain liberation;

Twenty-third, for those who are the most venerable among merchants, if they lack provisions on the way, he immediately manifests his spiritual power, provides them with companions, water, food and drink to satisfy them, and preaches the sutras for them;

Twenty-fourth, if there are people born blind, whether a hundred, a thousand, or ten thousand, he also uses his spiritual power to manifest to the blind, provides them with clothing, food and drink, and causes the blind to regain their eyesight, all rejoicing, and gradually preaches the Dharma for them, causing them all to aspire to seek the Buddha's path;

Twenty-fifth, in a great city, if there are prisoners seen in prison, he also transforms and becomes a prisoner, and also each in the midst of them uses the power of his spiritual power to cause the prisoners to be able to bathe, put on clothing, and eat food, and preaches the sutras for them, causing them all to aspire to seek the Buddha;

Twenty-sixth, if there are those who are about to be executed outside the city, the Bodhisattva will then use his majestic spiritual power, according to the number of people, to transform people to replace them. When the people are taken away, those people are freed, greatly joyful and delighted. He will then provide them with food and drink until they are full, and give them clothing. He will expound the scriptures and the Way for them. Those people, having been freed and experiencing joy and pleasure, will all arouse the intention to seek the Buddha's path.

Twenty-seventh, if there are disputes and lawsuits, whether over money and property or over fields and houses, the Bodhisattva will divide them equally in the middle and reconcile them. If there is not enough, he will use money and property to reconcile them, provide what is lacking, and later expound the scriptures and the Way for them, causing them to arouse the intention to seek the Buddha's path.
Twenty-eighth, with skillful means, the Bodhisattva always manifests as upright and shows himself to people as ugly and evil.

The music played by the gandharvas, mahoragas, and their retinues, as well as the music of the devas of the desire realm and the devas of the form realm, all sounded without being struck. On Fragrant Flower Mountain, the flowers and fruit trees all produced the sound of the qin, which was extremely beautiful.
The Buddha's entire body hair emitted light, each hair producing a lotus flower, and on each lotus flower sat a bodhisattva, all with the thirty-two marks.

By the Buddha's majestic spiritual power, the sounds of the music only spoke the sutra, all producing the sounds of the difficult sutra, like the doubts of people. The bodhisattvas sitting on the lotus flowers all sent forth questions about the difficult sutra, resolving all doubts.
All the sounds made a sound, saying:
How does one give rise to the bodhisattva mind and practice without forgetting, and thus attain sitting under the bodhi tree?
The bodhisattva replied:
The mind is joyful, and towards all there is boundless great compassion. For this reason, one does not forget.
The sound then asked again:
What is the intention?
What is the cause?
How does one give rise to boundless great compassion?
The bodhisattva replied:
The intention is not deceitful, the cause is like wisdom, and boundless great compassion leads to nirvana.
The sound then asked again:
What is giving? How does one already give?
How does one not regret what one has done?
How does one not seek rebirth?
How does one make the vow of a bodhisattva?
The bodhisattva replied:
One does not cherish possessions, and after giving, one has no regret.
Always thinking of the bodhisattva path, not seeking a place of rebirth.
The sound asked again:
How can one maintain pure precepts without being arrogant about them?
How can one teach those who have lost their precepts?
How can one attain the Mahayana?
The bodhisattva replied:
Those with a good mind have pure precepts.
Knowing that all dharmas are empty, one is not arrogant.
Practicing supreme great compassion, one can teach those who have lost their precepts.
The sound asked again:
If someone curses, beats, or wants to kill, how can one have patience?
How can one's mind not arise and yet be joyful?
The bodhisattva replied:
One should think:
'When I become a Buddha, I will be the king of physicians for all people, and I will cure the sick.
' For this reason, one can be patient.
If there are those who scold, beat, or want to kill them, their minds do not arise and they are joyful.
The sound then asked:
What is diligence? What is its completion?
How does one avoid danger and accomplish the practice of a bodhisattva?
The bodhisattva replied:
Diligence is for the sake of the Dharma and for the sake of protecting all beings. Its completion is in understanding the matter of emptiness, and thus one avoids danger.
The sounds then asked again:
How should the mind be so as to be fully equipped and deeply immersed?
How does one, in meditation, know that there is nothing to hope for?
The bodhisattva replied:
The mind is not confused, and thus it can be fully equipped;
the mind is not deceitful, and thus it is deeply immersed;
using skillful means, one is able to meditate.
For this reason, there is nothing to hope for.
The sounds then asked again:
How does one attain wisdom and insight, and practice straightforwardly?
How does one possess the wisdom of the Dharma and the work of the Dharma?
How can one resolve doubts?
The Bodhisattva replied:
One who delights in learning increases wisdom and understands the twelve links of dependent origination, thus being able to practice straightforwardly.
Because one delights in giving the Dharma, one can resolve doubts and understand their basis.
The sounds asked again:
How can one have much wisdom and be able to attain it through hearing?
How can one teach others and attain honor oneself?
The Bodhisattva replied:
Because one is always humble, one has much wisdom. If one practices what one hears, one can attain it. Because one gives the Dharma without expecting anything in return, one can attain the highest.
The sounds asked again:
What is compassion, and how does it lead to ultimate great compassion?
How does one possess the equal protection of the Dharma?
How can one attain the Brahma Heaven?
The Bodhisattva replied:
The mind of equality is compassion, the mind of non-abandonment is protection. Because of this, the mind is joyful and delighted, and one can reach the Brahma Heaven.
The sounds asked again:
How can bodhisattvas see the Buddha?
Having seen, how can they rejoice?
How can they hear the Dharma without doubt?
The bodhisattva replied:
Because the mind always thinks of the Buddha, one can attain seeing and hearing the Dharma;
Because the mind is pure, one can be without doubt.
The sounds asked again:
How can merit be accumulated?
How can wisdom be united?
How can contemplation be known?
How can such matters be sought?
The bodhisattva replied:
Because of being insatiable with merit, one accumulates learning without satiation, and thus attains wisdom.
The mind is not disturbed and has no thoughts, therefore it is called heading towards contemplation twenty-four.
The sounds asked again:
What is the place of the storehouse?
What is the practice?
What is the object of contemplation twenty-five?
The Bodhisattva replied:
The storehouse is empty and non-existent.
The place is the perfections and the four dhyanas. This is the practice. The object is to liberate all twenty-six.
The sounds asked again:
What are the affairs of Mara?
What are the affairs of the Buddha?
What is the practice that reaches the Bodhisattva twenty-seven?
The Bodhisattva replied:
Having no courage and being timid, this is called the affairs of Mara.
Following the mind of Mahayana, this is called the affairs of the Buddha.
Completely abandoning all evil, therefore attaining the Bodhisattva twenty-eight.
The sounds asked again:
How should one be close to a good friend?
How does one avoid bad teachers?
How does one abide equally?
How does one abandon the twenty-ninth?
The Bodhisattva replied:
Those who teach the Bodhisattva path are the spiritual friends;
Those who cause one to abandon the Bodhisattva mind are the bad teachers.
One acts with self-knowledge, therefore abiding equally;
Abandoning non-Buddhist paths and heterodoxies, this is the thirtieth.
The sounds further asked:
How can one protect all dharmas?
How can one teach all people?
How does one use skillful means to accomplish the Bodhisattva path thirty-first?
The Bodhisattva replied:
Through diligence, one can protect the Dharma;
Through skillful means, one can teach others.
Following people, whether on the path or in the world, and guiding them, one accomplishes the Bodhisattva path thirty-second.
The sounds further asked:
What is meant by 'what is done with wisdom'?
What are the affairs of Mara?
How does one carefully instruct without missing the right time?
The Bodhisattva replied:
What is done without fault is done with wisdom. What is done contrary to the Dharma is an affair of Mara.
Always following its teachings is careful instruction. Always being humble and respectful is being respected by others.
The sounds asked again:
What is the path?
What is not the path?
How does one cause people to enter the path?
The Bodhisattva replied:
The six perfections are the path.
The urgent matters of the Sravakas and Pratyekabuddhas are not the path of the Bodhisattvas.
By understanding prajna paramita and skillful means, one can cause people to enter the path.
The sounds asked again:
What is meant by 'benefit'?
What is the pacification?
How can it bring joy to those who are diligent and suffering?
The Bodhisattva replied:

Having taught the Dharma, there is no hunger or thirst, which is the joy.

The Bodhisattva replied:
Wisdom is the mother, the Dharma is the father, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment are the relatives, and the merits are the retinue. Therefore, one can love all.

The Bodhisattva replied:
Understanding empty things, one knows there is no self. This is great compassion, because one knows that all people are empty.
All birth and death have no principle of birth and death that causes it. One who knows this is also subject to birth and death.
The truth is that there is no going, no returning, and no abiding. One who acts like this can reach the Way.
Emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, having already gone to seek, is a single characteristic.
Having already known, one understands the emptiness of the five aggregates, therefore there are no thoughts;
Because there are no thoughts, there are no wishes. The single characteristic is without number.
The five aggregates are empty. Having already known the contemplation, the five aggregates are also known. Contemplating all people are completely empty, they are neither existent nor nonexistent.
Wisdom is the protector of emptiness, skillful means protects all people, having great compassion teaches others, therefore one can reach nirvana.
The sounds asked again:
Because there is no birth, there is nothing. All dharmas are like this. What is born is subtle, yet there is birth and death.
The Bodhisattva replied:
Because there is no birth, there is nothing. Therefore, the extinction of wisdom, because of the subtlety of skillful means, there is birth and death.
The sounds asked again:
What is meant by attaining certainty?
What is meant by not returning?
What is meant by attaining forbearance?
What is meant by being without doubt?
The Bodhisattva replied:

Equally abiding, one attains certainty. Having entered the Dharma body, one does not return. Having attained the forbearance of the joy of the Dharma born of non-production, one is then without doubt.

The bodhisattva replied:
The Buddha tree is like the sky, covering everything.
Practicing all dharmas is the characteristic of a bodhisattva, and therefore he is called a Buddha.
Because of wisdom, there is no hope in the mind, and the body is also like this, and therefore he is called TathÄgata.
